USDA NASS: income, expenses, labor, size, d2c sales

USDA ERS Food Environment Atlas: WIC, SNAP, grocery store density
USDA Farm Service Agency Disaster Assistance: emergency declarations (proxy for EWE)
USDA Food and Nutrition Service Farm to School program: SNAP and WIC eligibility rates, coverage rates, school food authority spending, farm to school program, culturally relevant foods

EPA National Aquatic Surveys: water quality, conditions based on phosphorus, nitrogen, habitat complexity,
TreeMap 2016: carbon stocks, forest health
NatureServe - biodiversity data, ecosystem data

title: Sustainability MetricsSecondary Data
text:
Methods: Desirable Directions



How do we decide if values for an indicator are good or bad?
Schneider et al. (2023) gave every indicator a positive and negative direction
Jacobi et al. (2020) used official benchmarks where possible, otherwise the largest value set to 100%
Others have used the distance to a reference system (Adriaanse 1993)

title: Sustainability MetricsSecondary Data
text:
Methods: Transformations

RawWinsorBox Cox




Raw Values

Do nothing
Strengths:

Transparent
Unbiased

Weaknesses:

Vulnerable to outliers
Harder to distinguish between similar systems






Hammond et al. (2017)





Winsorization

Reduce extreme values to a percentile (95th and 5th)
Strengths:

Doesn’t reward overperformance
Allows for more robust analyses without outliers (Mayer 2008)

Weaknesses

Loss of information
Non-linear transformation of data

Used in the Environmental Performance Indicator (EPI) before scaling from 0 to 100 (D. Esty 2008)



Box Cox (Bickel and Doksum 1981)

Finds an optimal value of \(\lambda\) to normalize distribution

\({\rm For}\ \lambda\neq0,\ f\lambda(x) = (sign(x)|x|^\lambda-1)/\lambda\)
\({\rm For}\ \lambda = 0,\ f_0(x) = log(x)\)

Strengths:

More tractable distributions for analysis

Weaknesses:

Challenging to interpret
Changes relationships between variables

Béné et al. (2019) used Box Cox transformations on skewed indicators (>2) before using min-max scaling.

title: Sustainability MetricsSecondary Data
text:
Methods: Rescaling

Rank OrderMin MaxZ-ScoresDistance*




Rank Order

Rank against other states (50 is best, 1 is worst)
Strengths:

Makes no distributional assumptions
Useful for comparing other transformation methods

Weaknesses:

Loss of information

Used by Schneider et al. (2025) for lack of robust data





Schneider et al. (2023)







Min Max (OECD 2008)

Scales all data from 0 (worst) to 1 (best)

\(I^t_qc = \frac{x^t_qc - min_c(x^{t_0}_q)}{max_c(x^{t_0}_q)-min_c(x^{t_0}_q)}\)
Where \(x^t_qc\) is the metric \(q\) for state \(c\) at time \(t\).

Strengths:

Intitive, approachable
Linear transformation preserves relationships

Weaknesses:

Susceptible to outliers

Widely used in sustainability composite indices Béné et al. (2019)





Jacobi et al. (2020)





Z-Scores (OECD 2008)

Scales data to mean of 0 and standard deviation of 1

\(I^t_{qc} = \frac{x^t_{qc}-x^t_{qc=\overline{c}}}{\sigma^t_{qc=\overline{c}}}\)

Larger numbers are better, but no limits
Linear transformation
Harder to interpret



Distance to Target (OECD 2008)

Dimensionless ratio of the indicator to a reference system or reference value

\(I^t_qc = \frac{x^t_qc}{x^t_{qc=\overline{c}}}\)

Used with official benchmarks like minimum wage (Jacobi et al. 2020)
Flexible and intuitive premise
Challenging to set targets in many applications

text:
Methods: Aggregation and Weighting

ArithmeticGeometricBudget*PCA*Others*


Arithmetic Means

Plain old average
Strengths:

Simple, interpretable
Know how it’s wrong

Weaknesses:

Compensatory method - make up for underperformance in one area with overperformance in another
Implicit equal weighting

Commonly used in composite index literature (Jacobi et al. 2020)



Geometric Means

\(n\)th root of the product of values

\(\Large \sqrt[n]{x_1 * x_2 * ... * x_n}\)

Strengths:

Partially compensable
Rewards even performance across areas

Weaknesses:

Not compatible with negative values*
Limits to variance-based sensitivity analysis

Gómez-Limón and Sanchez-Fernandez (2010) compared results of both arithmetic and geometric means
Béné et al. (2019) used arithmetic means for social and food dimensions, geometric means for environmental and economic dimensions



Budget Allocation (Nardo et al. 2005)

Weight based on expert or stakeholder opinion

Allocate a budget of 100 ‘points’ to distribute among indicators
Take means of allocations to get weights
Discussion, iteration, convergence

Strengths:

Leverage knowledge and experience
Flexible and holistic

Weaknesses:

Participant selection
Limited generalizability




Principal Components Analysis

Reduces variables to a smaller set of uncorrelated components
Loadings show contribution of variables to component
Strengths:

Empirical, quantitative results

Weaknesses:

Extraction
Interpretation
Incompatible with a priori hypotheses

Use loadings to weight indicators, calculate weighted sum as domain score (Nicoletti 2000)
D. C. Esty, Granoff, and Ruth (2002) tried PCA to develop composite but found the components were uninterpretable



Analytic Hierarchy Process

Analysis of pairwise preferences
Quantify tradeoffs between indicators

Conjoint Analysis

Survey-based
Stated preference research
Discrete choice analysis

Multicriteria Approach (Nardo et al. 2005)

Non-compensatory, based on pair-wise ratio comparisons between units

Data Envelopment Analysis (OECD 2008)

Use an efficiency frontier to define relative performance of countries

title: Sustainability MetricsSecondary Data
text:
Case Study: Validation by Cronbach
Raw + min max scaling + geometric aggregation



Cronbach’s Alpha is a measure of internal reliability or consistency (Cronbach 1951)
Arbitrary guideline of 0.7 to validate a measurement tool (Taber 2018) \[\begin{equation}
\alpha=\frac{n}{n-1}\left( 1-\frac{\sum_{i}^{V_i}}{V_t} \right)
\end{equation}\] Where \(n\) is the number of items, \(V_t\) is the variance of item \(i\), and \(V_t\) is the variance of all items
It is not supposed to be negative.











Context for Cronbach: not necessarily what we want, just one way to show consistency within dimension.
Might be okay if dimension is scattered

title: Sustainability MetricsSecondary Data
text:
Case Study: Validation by PCA



Principal Components Analysis is a dimension reduction method
Characterize variance of many variables using smaller set of components
Guideline: loadings > 0.32 are meaningful (Tabachnick, Fidell, and Ullman 2019)
Key to loadings:

x < 0.2 ~ ’ ’
x < 0.32 ~ ‘.’
x >= 0.32 ~ x












PA: randomize rows, do PCA. Keep PCs that explain significantly more variance than expected by chance
MAP: get average squared partial correlations for each PC. Keep PCs that lead to lowest average squared partial correlation
VSS: compare fit of simplified model to original correlations. VSS = 1-sumsquares(r*)/sumsquares(r). Peaks at optimal (most interpretable) number of factors.
Promax is best interpretation, but not great
Loadings: correlation coefficients between variables and components
Eigenvalue (ss loadings): varaince explained by component
Communality (h2): proportion of common variance present in variable
Uniqueness (u2): unique variable for each var (1-h2)
Complexity (com): how well it reflects a construct (1 for 1, loading evenly on 2 is 2)
